basics.name: Matthew Frosst
basics.summary: A PhD candidate in computational astrophysics, searching for the next step in their career.

work.name: Queen's University
work.summary: Led team to provide data analysis and data visualisation support using Python, R, and SQL, to the Queen's University Physics Department.
highlights: Communicated key analytics to leadership through technical reports, custom dashboards, and presentations.
Resulted in statistically significant increases in student retention and test scores, and a reduced workload for teaching assistants.

volunteer.organization: International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
volunteer.summary: Attended monthly Senior Staff meetings to advocate oh behalf of the interests of PhD Students.
highlights: Oversaw PhD stipend increase of 1,200 USD.
Initiated the creation of a 45,000 USD cash pool for article publication fees.
Helped to reorganise the PhD annual milestone system to promote efficiency and high-quality research.

volunteer.organization: International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
volunteer.position: Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) Committee Student Representative
volunteer.summary: Participated as student representative to the ICRAR DEI committee.
highlights: Organised workshops discussing the professional development and mental health of students and early-career researchers.

Oversaw the creation of the Renu Sharma Scholarship in Astronomy and Astrophysics which provides 10,000 AUD for women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders studying astronomy and astrophysics at the University of Western Australia.

education.institution: University of Western Australia, International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research

awards.title: Science Support Discretionary Fund Recipient
awards.summary: Competitive funding which supports early-career researchers and PhD students to travel and work at ESO HQ in Munich, Germany.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
